Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: threat or non-threat. Threatening someone means implying that someone will be hurt even if they do not do something specific.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Opening up people of a different race to violent acts including death by idiots, by inciting her followers to violence, is offensive. If anything happens to the Jones family, Dembroski should be charged as an accessory.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Comment: "who do you think should do the killing?"

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. As I said above: remove all protections on free ranging cats, and allow people to help. People who allow their pets to roam outside are part of the problem, because their pets are part of the problem. It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

But if you look back at the records of the strongest storms (in terms of max sustained winds, 1 min. avg) the data show a disproportionate number of them occurred in the more recent decades (my first quick look at Atlantic hurricanes showed 6 of the top 7 occurring since 1980, for instance.)

Feel free to go ahead and continue spouting lies while ignoring what the data says to further your head-in-the-sand agenda.

Simple physics states that warmer water carries more energy, warmer air can cold more moisture.  Observations conclude the air has warmed, the oceans have warmed, and the seas have risen in the last 100 years.  How could these NOT affect what hurricanes do?

Comment: Financial access to post-secondary education is certainly a critical factor. But when looking at countries like the U.S. and U.K., it is essential to consider how the education system is structured. In Miles Corak's comparative analysis of inter-generationality income mobility, the three worst countries were the U.S., U.K. and France. France? Yet France has very low tuition for university. 

What is common among these three inequitable countries? Universities that are established to reproduce social class. Ivy League and other private universities in the U.S. 'Oxbridge' in the the U.K. And the grandes écoles in France. All three systems are fed by large private and exclusionary primary education systems. Essentially, a two tier system of post-secondary learning. Of course, the upper tier is not simply providing academic knowledge, it is shaping the cultural and social capital for the future upper class.

There are a number of problems causing this, but the bottom line is the Obamacare mandate is not strong enough get everyone to purchase insurance. The original mandate idea came from conservative Republicans including Gingrich and was first implemented by Romney in Massachusetts and the idea is that almost everyone would get insurance (they said we have the greatest insurance in the world and all we need is to make everyone get private insurance). Even the current House plan has a mandate-- you go off insurance for more than 2 months and you get hit with a tax surcharge. How to handle group plans is still vague.

Comment: Strada, I did some math. During the school year, I teach 38 weeks, 7 hours/day, 5 days/week.  38 x 35 = 1330 hours. Yes, shy of 1800 hours/year. However, I grade, communicate with parents, do extra required paperwork, etc. 3-5 more hours/day.  I'll use the low number and call it 3 extra hours/day x 5 days/week plus 5 hours on Sunday, so that's an extra 20 hours/week x 38 weeks = 760 extra hours (again this is minimal). 1330 + 760 = 2090 per school year.  This does not include: classes to keep my teaching certificate valid (+ extra I choose to take), required trainings on my own time before school starts, staff meetings, teaching myself new curriculum, differentiating curriculum for students, meeting with EVERY family during conferences (sometimes x 2 bc of divorced parents), prepping work due to minimal parent support, and SO much more. This does not include the lesson planning I do in the summer. I work more in 38 weeks than some do in 52. I am not the exception. What about MY family?

Comment: Another issue that has been ignored is the unfair or inequitable treatment of homeowners and other asset owners regarding income on capital gains. In a logical world all income would be taxed the same. This would include salaries, capital gains on home sales, professional income, and capital gains on stock or other asset sales. This would go a long way to take some of the heat out of the real estate and stock markets, as both are inflated assets (aka bubbles). But if one wishes to maintain the capital gains exemptions on homes, it could be made more equal if it was a once in a lifetime thing and it was only for the average value of a home in Canada at the time of the claim, so the playing field was more equitable or equal. Increasing the holding period from one year to a five year minimum, with the holder being required to have paid personal income tax in Canada for that period might also help. These are all understandable and addressable issues.

Comment: Startmail.com puts your privacy first, with excellent encryption ... and Countermail.com doesn't even have hard-drives in their servers, no record at all of any of your e-mails.  Both are based in Europe, which has much better privacy laws.  Both accept debit and credit cards.  I recommend against creating an "auto-pay" Pay-Pal account to pay them though, they have proven to be mercenary.  I had to close a debit card account, just to get Pay-Pal's grubby mitts out of it.  Processing a "one-time" debit or credit card payment through Pay-Pal is safe.
Only the "free" e-mail services have similar risks as Yahoo, as they have to data-mine your account, to be able to charge advertisers.  I pay Countermail.com 60 bucks per year, and it has been worth every penny.

Comment: Toronto does not believe in advanced green lights for left turns.  Many intersections have them at rush hour only. Comment: The issue ScienceDuck is that by using her own email server to store her emails (which no one else has ever done, despite the misstatement by Wills to the contrary), Clinton gave herself complete and sole control and access to her email archive, even though it was being used for official government business.  The difference between Clinton and Rice or Powell is that they also had government email accounts, which they primarily used for their official business.  Clinton, however, NEVER had a govt account.  ALL of her email went through her own private server

If she had used a govt account, like Rice and Powell, then the government would have access to the server containing the emails.  And if you use a commercial email service like Hotmail, as an example, Microsoft controls and has access to the server that the email resides on.

Clinton basically stored her emails where no one else would have access to them, even though she was conducting government business.   How convenient is that?

Comment: That's not at all what Paine or our Founding Fathers thought about rights. Their belief in rights was a direct product of the Enlightenment and the Judeo-Christian paradigm: God grants us our rights, and it is up to government to uphold those rights- NOT create them, as you suggest when you said "[the Colonists] could all have rights within their own country."  Government doesn't take or give rights- they uphold the rights we already have, with or without government telling us we do.
.
When you declare that "healthcare is a right" you directly contradict our Founding Fathers how free people feel about rights.  Answer this question:  If healthcare is a "right," then whose labor and talents are you entitled to?  The answer is "No one." You are never entitled to someone else's time, labor, or efforts.  No one has a right to my time or labor- this principle is underscored in both the DOI and our Constitution.

Comment: Large assemblages of people can't help but encounter criticism, it seems. 

Focus on few specific issues, and you invite criticism about how those 'rights' are not exclusionary from other basic global human rights. Focus on broader issues, and you invite criticism about how your 'movement' is just a grab-bag litany of catch-all issues, rudderless without a purpose or vision. 

As a recent immigrant to Canada, I am always glad when people can march peacefully and freely a mark of solidarity for issues we care deeply about. Makes me happy and grateful to be living in a healthy and vibrant democracy. Perhaps events like this can lead to greater reflection and deliberation on what our values are, and what priorities we should be striving for as a nation. 

Cheers, and thanks for reading.

Comment: Nice Mike - good to read.  As a kid growing up, our family fished the Kenai from the Russian River to the Skilak cut-off  from 1960 to early 70's when I went off to school. That section of river  back then understood to be closed to sport fishing for kings. In Late August to early October (as late as we fished), we would find huge spawned out kings wash up on the beaches and in the eddies  as the water dropped. I'm guessing they were main stem spawners using that portion of the river.  I wonder if that portion was ever opened for king fishing or if they still spawn in that section? Voluntary conservations could help and it would be wonderful to restore those huge fish.

Comment: Amidst the smoke and mirrors, raising taxes on local governments, cuts to seniors and education, there's one budget item that was not reduced: The money set aside for Legislator Salary Padding.

http://www.adn.com/sites/default/files/2015%20Legislative%20Travel%20Report.pdf

During the regular session in Juneau, legislators get about $235/day for lodging and food. A recent House report shows that Rep. Reinbold paid $850 in rent plus $100 in utilities, a total of $950/month. Rep. Vasquez paid $650 in rent, plus $100 in utilities, a total of $750. Both legislators received about $235 per day, or $7,000 per month for room and board, meaning that each of them is receiving over $6,000- tax free,  per month  above actual lodging expenses.  

And Juneau legislators  get 75% of the federal per diem rate, or about $175 per day- $5,000 per month of session- for living in their own homes.

http://www.alaskapublic.org/2015/06/12/legislatures-per-diem-expenses-approach-200k/

Comment: Bone broth worked for me. I had to give up running for 30 years, but took it up again in my 50s on daily bone broth. I recommend organic bone broth. Over 20% of the amino acid content in collagen/gelatin is glycine. Glyphosate is a synthetic analogue of glycine and gets taken up to replace glycine in protein synthesis in the body, resulting in misfolding and impaired protein functionality, including degrading the ferro-magnetic "spring" properties of the collagen triple helix molecule. Animals that are fed glyphosate-sprayed crops ingest the glyphosate, which is released from the plant proteins they digest. The animal incorporates glyphosate as it makes collagen, which taints bone broth made from animals fed glyphosate-treated crops. People vary in their vulnerability to glyphosate. A recent study of MS patients found higher levels of glyphosate incorporated into their collagen protein than controls

Comment: Wrong again, Tempmanoa.  The thing you call a treaty was not a treaty.  It was the “Agreed Framework” between the USA and the DPRK, signed in October 1994 under which North Korea was to freeze and eliminate its plutonium-producing reactors. In exchange, NK was to receive two light water reactors and annual shipments of heavy fuel oil during construction of the reactors, funded by the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO), a multinational consortium.  The International Atomic Energy Agency sealed and placed surveillance equipment on NK’s nuclear power plants.  NK violated the agreement in December 2002 by cutting off the locks and disrupting surveillance equipment.  It kicked IAEA inspectors out of the country, restarted its nuclear reactors and withdrew from the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty.  Bush tore up nothing.  NK simply refused to live up to the terms of the agreement, causing it to fall apart.

Comment: Transport Canada needs to cover the cost of keeping inspectors current because we're not talking about an hour of solo circuits in a 172 at $165.00 per hour here.  I have flown with a Transport Canada inspector who used to fly one of their Cessna Citations IFR between Ottawa and Hamilton to stay current.  The Aircraft Owners & Pilots Association had the hourly variable expenses for a Cessna Citation Mustang at $1,015.37 U.S. last November.  I found a place in the U.S. that will rent a Mustang for $1,200.00 per hour dry.  Add the variable expenses and we're at $2,215.37 U.S. per hour.  Add a Mustang instructor at $150.00 U.S. per hour and we're at $2,365.37 U.S. per hour.  If we use an exchange rate of 35% then we are at $3,193.25 Canadian per hour of dual.

Comment: A family member of mine was in an acute care bed in Peterborough waiting for an MRI. I was in the room when we were told it could be 3-4 days until she had the MRI, which was necessary to see if she could be safely discharged. I was stunned. "3-4 days in an acute care bed waiting for an MRI? Aren't you running them 24/7 like they do downtown?" I asked. "Oh yes, was the reply, but we only have limited slots for in-patients, Emerg comes first. I don't make the rules here. There may be spaces before then but we really don't know". Meanwhile, she had waited 2 overnights in the emergency to even get into the bed. No wonder there are no acute beds. This system is really messed up. Brand new hospital, silly rules and people on gurneys in the emergency department almost from the day the place opens.  Of course, had she been mobile we could easily have paid for a private MRI right away. I put up a fuss and surprise, she got scheduled the next day. Wow

Comment: Look no matter what as long as the commission is NON-NEGOTIABLE and is paid from the seller then no matter what, the buyer is not going to be "properly represented".  Simple economics and human behavior tell you that both the seller's agent and the buyer's agent want one thing at the end of the day...the deal to close and the price to be as HIGH as possible so their commissions are as HIGH as possible.  As a buyer I NEVER trusted my Agent, EVER.  At the end of the day he/she did not work for me, he was facilitating the sale and  had a vested interest in ensuring he got his commission (non-negotiable). Who did I trust in the process?  My wife (one of the most savvy business people I know)  and my very experienced real estate lawyer.   

Buying real estate in Toronto can be a painful, expensive and miserable experience (especially where you are buying a one wall reno with no warranty & no inspection  from a numbered company).  Do yourself a favour, do your research and trust no one.

Comment: So you disagree with the Heller historical analysis (which overthrew nothing) and yet cling to a misread of Section III?

Note that the "longstanding restrictions" noted were particularized time, place, and manner restrictions (most explicitly racially based) on -use- of a weapon, often by clearly defined legal subsets (and often not "long-standing," as in the case of, say, felons in general, which dates only to 1968), not general bans on a particular class of firearm (clearly covered in Section IV). As to "dangerous and unusual," the full historical references are primarily to carriage, usually modified with intent to terrify, not mere possession nor even definition.  

While I agree many people who cite it haven't read Heller, equally bad are people who merely read it (or cut and paste what others have published) solely to pull out what they -think- supports their pet position, but who don't bother to look further.

Comment: I'm not a big fan of either, but I've seen both, if you can count the first three Star Wars movies and a random smattering of different Star Trek episodes as having seen them. 

Of course you have an apples and oranges problem in making the comparison, because the scope of the two projects – objectives, budgets, people involved, and all things creative – were so different. Trek was conceived to sell ads on network TV, right? Wars was a Lucas/Spielburg extravaganza. Sure, Trek became a series of movies too, but that was afterthought. So it bothers me that you cite history based on the movies with Star Wars first, when Star Trek actually started almost two decades earlier than Star Wars, in 1966, as a television show. 

Production values, star power, effects, of course all go to Star Wars, and there is budget and objectives behind that. But Star Trek did start earlier, paved the way, and had a long history of different people involved, with an interesting flair for putting real human problems (racism, for example, a recurring theme in Star Trek as the different races dealt with each other) into a new perspective. And there's interesting comparisons on the big picture, too ... the great Yoda perspective and quotes, of course, and the whole power of the force, in Star Wars. But Trek embraced big picture too, like the larger collective metaphor of Seven of Nine. 

I wish you'd done a straight compare and contrast, instead of which is better. Better will always be subjective, and it's too close ended, in my opinion.

Comment: Please check your facts.  UH does not play a "minor league schedule".  There are 774 U.S. colleges and universities that field football teams and UH is among the 130 at the highest level (Football Bowl Subdivision).  UH's future football schedule includes non-conference games against the Pac-12's UCLA, Arizona, Washington, Oregon State, Oregon and Arizona State, the Big 10's Wisconsin and the SEC's Vanderbilt.  UH's Mountain West conference typically puts a team in the Top 25 (3%) each year, including San Diego State in 2016.

Regarding academic standing, the NSF places UH 74th among 895 ranked U.S. research institutions with $316 million in research spending, just behind Colorado State at 73rd with $317 million.  In the Carnegie Foundation research classifications, UH has the highest "R1: Doctoral Universities – Highest Research Activity" rating, the same as Colorado State.  In the USNWR rankings, UH (169th) and Colorado State (129th) are in the same tier of "National Universities".

Comment: I returned last night from Houston, Texas. The devastation can not be fully appreciated unless personally experienced.

The unrelenting rain and almost hourly flash flood and tornado alerts were overwhelming . I witnessed the worst nature can throw at us, and I also witnessed, first hand, the best of human kindness, caring, and love!

Comment: There are various ways to manage risk.  Some investors work around a core portfolio of stocks that are never sold.  Then in the periphery there are companies that may be regarded as smaller, non-core positions. These can be sold if they have run up or if fundamentals seem to have changed.  Another idea is to sell half a  position that has really gone up and let the other half keep running.  Put the proceeds into short-term MMF or high-interest savings and then wait for opportunities.  I like the idea of focusing on individual companies and not "the market."  For instance, the market seems to have decided that bank earnings are going to explode, while telecoms are now in the doghouse because of the fear of rising rates.  So I recently added to BCE on weakness, despite a strong quarterly report and a 5% dividend increase.  BCE could tread water or even go down more, but that dividend is going to provide a floor under the price, and when markets do crash, BCE tends to hold up better.

Comment: All republics with a parliamentary system have a head of state usually called a "President" ---though the office could be called "governor" or "governor-general" or "king" or "big cheese" or whatever---and a head of government usually called a "Prime Minister" -- in Germany the title is "Chancellor".  If you think about it for a while, you'll realize why it is important to have a head of state distinct from the head of government in a parliamentary system.  The US is unusual in having a head of state but no head of government whose position is dependent on the ability to command support from a legislative assembly.

Comment: I'm not a big fan of either, but I've seen both, if you can count the first three Star Wars movies and a random smattering of different Star Trek episodes as having seen them. 

Of course you have an apples and oranges problem in making the comparison, because the scope of the two projects – objectives, budgets, people involved, and all things creative – were so different. Trek was conceived to sell ads on network TV, right? Wars was a Lucas/Spielburg extravaganza. Sure, Trek became a series of movies too, but that was afterthought. So it bothers me that you cite history based on the movies with Star Wars first, when Star Trek actually started almost two decades earlier than Star Wars, in 1966, as a television show. 

Production values, star power, effects, of course all go to Star Wars, and there is budget and objectives behind that. But Star Trek did start earlier, paved the way, and had a long history of different people involved, with an interesting flair for putting real human problems (racism, for example, a recurring theme in Star Trek as the different races dealt with each other) into a new perspective. And there's interesting comparisons on the big picture, too ... the great Yoda perspective and quotes, of course, and the whole power of the force, in Star Wars. But Trek embraced big picture too, like the larger collective metaphor of Seven of Nine. 

I wish you'd done a straight compare and contrast, instead of which is better. Better will always be subjective, and it's too close ended, in my opinion.

Comment: "The medical cost of supporting tobacco's victims is huge, one we all bear."

In Oregon, over $2 of the price of a pack of cigarettes is tax (federal and state combined). "As of 11 a.m. ET on Friday, Metro counted 193,000 rides, less than half the 513,000 it counted in 2009 and far fewer than the 317,000 it did for Obama’s second inauguration, in 2013. On Saturday, Metro counted 275,000 trips before  11 a.m., also surpassing the figure from the previous morning."

I agree that this is a largely peripheral issue, but the public debate about it wouldn't be now taking place had Trump's camp not exacerbated it. Maybe Republican supporters just don't take the subway, but the Metro rider numbers seem to corroborate the photographic evidence. Trump's people should move on and deal with more important matters.

Comment: Bud,

I'm sure that many people share your aversion to income redistribution and you are certainly entitled to your opinion.

The difficulties with the welfare system to which my earlier comment refers are an unavoidable consequence of that aversion (unless, of course, one takes the extreme position that no public monies should be spent to provide welfare in any form - which has its own set of dire consequences).

Your position also fails to take account of the fact that robotics, information technology and the communication revolution amongst other trends are shifting income from the human workforce to the providers of capital - ergo, growing income and wealth gaps over the past 3 or more decades.  This will only get worse over the next decades and the resulting suppression of status and wellbeing for the large majority of the population cannot be justified on moral grounds implied in your comment.

Comment: Senior lifetime passes have gone up from $10 to $80 as of August 27, 2017.  You can get them at national parks, but there are none on Oahu, so you would have to go to the Big Island.  You can do it by mail but it costs an extra $10 processing fee and you have to submit ORIGINAL proof of citizenship and age.  The following are needed: (1)  A U.S. State or Territory issued Driver’s License, Identification or Birth Certificate; (2) A U.S. Passport or Passport Card; or (3) A Permanent Resident Card (Green Card).  They have a backlog of at least three months.  So if you dare, send in your originals.  Driver's License? Sure thing. I guess I can drive without one for three months or so.  This was so much BS, I decided it wasn't worth it.

Comment: Be honest and ask yourself: What is a "responsible drinker?  In all fairness to pot smokers, the main reason to smoke or ingest these things is an "effect" on the human body.  "Responsible" drinkers would hardly support the vast alcohol industry and all the "effects" of alcohol, both good and bad, have been well-documented. The "bad effects" contribute to the imbalance of insurance, health care and long-term detriments to society everywhere in the world. Those who have studied the "effects" of pot ingestion worldwide, see some similarities but not the degree of devastation of alcohol abuse.  The "responsible drinker" comes up against one serious problem; the tolerance effect of alcohol.  In order to achieve the same "effect" long-term, I think it is well-documented that larger doses are needed.  So logically, a "responsible drinker" is one who never builds tolerances, e.g. not drinking for the "effect." Both pot and alcohol users drink for "effect" - a fact, for better or worse.

Comment: The quote from the CDC is a little out of date, because assays developed over the last decade have shown that statistically more cases of Toxoplasma gondii are contracted from fecal oocysts now (in the USA) than from tissue cysts,  such as found in meat.  This is likely due to several factors, including excluding cats from meat production.  The oocysts are the more common source of infection, which can occur from drinking contaminated water, inhalation of contaminated playground dust, contaminated dirt under fingernails, children putting fingers in their mouth that has previously contacted contaminated soil or water, etc.  Remember, we are talking about infectious oocysts that you can't see with your naked eye, millions of them, shed from a single infected cat, lasting over a year in soil or water.  It takes only one oocyst to infect a pig under lab conditions, which is a model for humans.  Cat colonies and outdoor cats shed the most oocysts into the environment, versus indoor cats.

Comment: I disagree a bit on HPR's responsibility.  If Sai were advocating on HPR that listeners pay Perfect Title and stop paying their mortgage, then, yes, a discussion of Sai's conviction and the consequences of his advice would be germane.

But Sai's ideas, which were a basis for his bad title advice, have a wide range of implications for important issues inside and outside academia.  I'm perfectly fine discussing them in this context without getting bogged down in the Perfect Title story. 

As for the "scary" part of reporters not knowing the full history behind a story, this is the distinction between journalism and investigative journalism.  One reports the now and the other augments the now with some historical background.  Given the pace of the news cycle and the flood of information reported nowadays, I don't think that will change.

Comment: Forty thousand years ago so much water was locked up in continental glacial ice that the Grand Banks off Newfoundland was dry land. A person living then could walk from what is now the Scottish Borders to modern day Berlin without Gortex boots. Wind back to 125K years ago, the peak of the last interglacial warm period. The seas then were 9 meters (27 feet) higher, and three full celcius degrees warmer than today. The Arctic Seas would have been ice free year round for thousands of years around the peak.. At a time when our ancestors wore animal skins and made knives by banging rocks against other rocks. 

The perspective of Geologic Time makes the tiny fluctuations in modern climate look like the wobbles on a seismograph when a truck passes on a highway a dozen miles away. Just plain insignificant.

Comment: State Championships aren't what they used to be.  The real brass ring is now a college scholarship and college admission.   The OIA is acknowledging it cannot compete regularly, and anyway the chances of a State Championship are one or two or three out of 67.   All it gets is temporary bragging rights.  Sometimes, the consequences of sports celebrity can be really bad if following a Championship, a player washes out as an adult (e.g. "Former State Championship Football Player Charged In . . . ").  There is far more positive publicity and pats on the head for getting a sholarship or getting a college education.   People rightly or wrongly think a private school education increase the chances of getting those two things.  So, for most private school families and students, icing private schools out of State tourneys by playing games is almost validation by vindictiveness, and definitely a minor insult in the grand scheme of things.  The OIA is only, tragically, highlighting that.

Comment: Pop is relatively inexpensive, but really not good when people drink a lot of it.  It's fine as an occasional treat.   

I buy the argument that public policy should look at the issues involved more broadly rather than rely on a tax as a quick fix.   However, the objective of public policy should be to encourage less consumption of soft drinks by many people than they consume now in a variety of ways.  Marketing is one way.   Looking at ways to support food quality (nutrients in food) is another.   Re-setting the healthcare system to place more emphasis on primary care and ensuring people don't have serious nutritional deficiencies is yet another.   Nutritional deficiencies are a surprisingly big problem in North America and the nutrient-deprived body and brain is a hungry body and brain that's likely to overeat and make a lot of poor food choices.

Some of these things will take a while.   It has taken decades to get where we are;  the pendulum won't swing back overnight.

Comment: i was actually excited when I saw this headline.  It has certainly seemed like Pt Orchard might have something to teach us  --  they have resisted the change in City status for so long.

But this is a puff piece, based on one interview with one representative of one side.  The real story is, Pt Orchard residents voted against the change in city status in 2013, and every few years before that.  This year, their city council changed tactics:  instead of asking citizens to vote and getting told "no" again, the council simply enacted the change and dared its citizens to stop it.  Sound familiar?  Only here it was fluoridation, not city status, and the city went to court to defeat the citizens' petition to stop it.

I've been pondering why PO's council would behave like this.  I finally figured it out  --  city governors like the change, because they have to play by fewer rules.  But city residents get nothing from the deal  -- except, perhaps, a more arrogant city government.

Comment: Large-scale attacks on Canada are vulnerable to discovery and prevention by the normal methods. The only kind of attack that can squeeze through that safety net is of the independent, 'lone-wolf' variety. On the scale of threats to their well-being that Canadians blandly face every day, the threat of a lone-wolf terrorist is insignificant. 

Bulk data collection is about getting that lone-wolf terrorist, about finding the needle in the haystack. The price that we pay for ameliorating that insignificant threat is mass surveillance of the entire population. 
Having a turn-key totalitarian state waiting in the wings is not the answer to the minimal threat that bulk data collection can only hope to prevent.

Comment: You would need figures on convictions in the different jurisdictions to get a gauge on what is a reasonable unfounded rate. Comment: “Nearly 180,000 illegal immigrants with criminal records, ordered deported from our country, are tonight roaming free to threaten peaceful citizens.”

This figure comes from a letter the Department of Homeland Security submitted to Congress in response to questions from staunchly anti-immigrant Senator Jeff Sessions (R-AL), in which the agency said they have no way to determine how many “aliens” have criminal convictions. 

The DHS, however, uses a very broad definition of “criminal.” Most “criminal” undocumented immigrants deported during the Obama years were actually convicted of minor crimes like traffic offenses or simply “illegal entry,” a petty misdemeanor under federal criminal law. Additionally, many immigrants ICE targets as criminals have no criminal conviction at all. Deportations of these “criminal” immigrants have risen drastically under Obama.

Comment: American chicanery over softwood lumber predates Trump by decades.  The inefficient US lumber industry gets the Commerce Department to bring charges of subsidization.  The case goes before an impartial tribunal and the Americans get told, "You have no case."

So the industry gets its tame weasels in Congress to weave around the law and Canada ends up paying its US competitors in order to continue having access to the market, where we supply 30 per cent of US lumber consumption -- and the highest quality portion of the market because our northern fibre is better than their easily warped yellow pine.

The answer:  stop shipping lumber south.  Let the federal and provincial governments provide no-interest loans to Canadian companies during the moratorium.  When the US construction industry finds it's paying through the nose for an inferior product, they'll mobilize their Congressional weasels.  Then the fight will be on, and US lumber will lose.  Once and for all.

Comment: I've learned over the years (and several inter-provincial moves) that friendships come and go. Too often, we think we're closer than we really are, so it takes more time to grieve the lost friendship than that friendship really deserves.  In addition, many people don't know how to say "it's over" in a non-threatening manner, so they simply say nothing, hoping that the other person won't find out they want to move on and forget them.  If a friend doesn't respond to an e-mail or letter, I normally write a second time after a while (to allow for the possibility of a lost message). If that second message is not answered, time to move on.  If it's been a long or close friendship, I'll write a 3rd time just to say farewell, for closure. In that message, I may say that I understand the friendship has run its course and that I won't write again unless I hear otherwise, or I just say "I appreciated our friendship while it lasted. Best wishes for the future." That's also good to end it first.

Comment: Alaska Airlines is implementing a Premium Economy (PE) program in January.  F Class is losing a row and more space (read:  legroom) is being created in rows 6-10.  Those rows now become the first landing for comp upgrades, i.e., row 6 will no longer be available for selecting at purchase time.  Even for those with elite status.  You will be able to choose a complimentary upgrade to PE and/or the F cabin.  Exit rows can still be selected at purchase (comp if you have status).  

Some of the planes have already been reconfigured and rows 6-10 appear to have approx. 80% the legroom of exit row.  And there is more legroom in F (esp. row 1).

If you have tix for flights in January w/seats in rows 6-10, be sure to check them often as uncontemplated reassignments have been happening.

Alaska has put up a PE portal page on its website and the Alaska Airlines Flyertalk page is another good source of info as the posters are very frequent travelers who bring a lot of knowledge to the table.

Comment: Your first statement is incorrect. It is illegal for a prohibited person to purchase or possess, or any person to knowingly provide them a firearm. That people can knowingly break a law does not make that act "perfectly legal."

Your second statement is also incorrect. A seller wanting a background check involved can require the buyer show a NICs-exempt, or, as you note, have the transaction take place through an FFL. The FFL is providing a service (and losing, in theory, a potential sale of one of their inventory guns) using their expensive (and paperwork intensive) license and taking up a half-hour or so of their time. They -should- get to set the cost. There are some in town last I looked who will do them for $25-35, since a dollar earned is a dollar earned and the firearm goes on and off their bound book in a matter of a half-hour or so.

Comment: Great tribute to a great man! Herb Kane knew how to combine his western trade skills of illustration with lost Polynesian knowledge. His imagery combine well researched facts, emotions, and engineering details. He would have resented to be put on the level of a da Vinci, but he followed similar principles. I.e. he studied, designed, physically built, sailed, then depicted the historical and emotional story of voyaging canoes. A respected, humble neighbor in our Honaunau community he always made a point of being half Hawaiian, half Westerner. From his experience in advertising he was aware that pictures speak more than words. What he didn't know is that his paintings would turn into the best P.R. campaign & history lesson Hawai'i will ever get, inspiring Hawaiians and the rest of the world.

Comment: That more people are for or against a particular president has no relevance as to the correctness of that president's actions. Most people in Germany were for Hitler. Most people supported Nixon until the last couple of years. Most people voted for Hillary.
The fallacy is argumentum ad populum (also known as appeal to democracy!).  Sure, we use popularity (mostly) in our elections, but even the majority can be wrong. Hopefully less so than the minority.
But the Framers knew this and established rights that would be very hard for the majority to deny. To deny certain rights the Constitution would have to be changed. That is hard, and by the time it reaches a vote, the passion for change often wanes. Still, mistakes can be made, as in Prohibition. 
It's an interesting read: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentum_ad_populum

Comment: Richard, if you get the chance attend one of the monthly briefings by Rick Thoman. 

https://accap.uaf.edu/NWS_Briefings

here's June's

https://accap.uaf.edu/sites/default/files/2016_Jul_Alaska_Region_Climate_Disco_Public.pdf

And monthly averages are exactly that, the average temperature for that month. If you were to say only look at the highs of that month, you would see more noise in the signal. A monthly average smooths that out. That's not to say there isn't value looking at the extremes, I looked at the lowest temperature every year in Fairbanks at the airport and found that the cold days are disappearing. In fact 2012 may be the last year -50 was observed at the airport, it used to be quite common here. This is completely expected in a warming climate.

The traffic cluster, especially in morning and afternoon rush, at the Ironwood shopping centre before the Massey tunnel is made worse because the City allowed the complex to be built without a long dedicated right hand turn lane southbound on Steveston Highway.  

Same for the new Gardens (retail and condo) complex on the other side of the road, the access lanes are totally inadequate.

What, when upzoning from acres of sf detached to 12 floors of condos and a huge shopping complex,  the City could not demand from the developer proper egress? Let alone allowing for  bike lanes, which they did not.

Btw, traffic from the new 10 lane Massey Bridge will feed into this congested area.

Comment: A lot of wrath unleashed on this board against people who doubt that humans are behind global warming.

I actually do not care if people doubt that humans are behind global warming.

I am more interested in peoples' policy preferences.

Do you support reducing factory emissions? Do you support lighter, fuel efficient cars? Do you support developing solar and wind and nuclear as alternatives to coal and natural gas? Does your family recycle? Does your family walk or bicycle whenever they can instead of driving?

If a person's response to all of the above is "yes", then I am perfectly okay if they think AL Gore is satan, think that man-made global warming is a hoax, and think that environmental activists are delusional.

It's all about the policy.

Comment: We all know the days where cars are in ditches everywhere.  Those days are not the days where we have a solid snow pack with stable temps as in that case studdless do as well or better than studded.  The days we see all the wrecks are when it warms up and rains over the cold soaked roads.  In that condition (again the one where everyone wrecks, and costs of life and property lose go up) anyone who claims studdless tires perform as well or better is lying to them self.  This happens several times a winter, and therefore studs are justified.  I have studded tires on one of my heavy vehicles and blizzaks on a truck and X-ices on a high powered car, and the studdless do perform better in several categories, but the one they fail in is the one that matters the most.

Comment: You are confusing two levels of government.  The Federal Government and the State of Oregon Government.

Eliminating Federal spending for the military or anything else will not necessarily result in any money coming to Oregon.  

There could be an increase in housing nationwide if the US Congress and President wanted to continue the same debt load for that purpose.  Or they could choose to spend it on bridges or roads.  Or not spend it at all and reduce the national debt.  

Not one of those decisions will necessarily send any money to Oregon for anything.

Oregon has to pay for its employees and all their benefits with its own money.  And, unlike the Federal Government, our ability to go into debt to do so is very limited.

Comment: I will admit that this is easier to understand in terms of unity of teaching with variety in application, but we are a sacramental church, so unity of practice should be doable. I'm not sure I am up to it, but maybe somebody is.
Take the Eucharist. For 1500+ years it was explained in terms of pre-Christian religious ritual, like sacrifice and altars. The final stage in a sacrifice is the sharing of the victim to enable a distribution of the numinous among the believers.
The same ritual can be reinterpreted from a different perspective. Instead of the sacrifice as explanatory key, the meal can be understood as Christ's purpose. Christ died so that we can share in his life. The concluding communal meal is a more effective key today than the rarely experienced ritual sacrifice, in a Church based on communion.
One event, understood in two ways, can easily become two different ways of experiencing a common practice. I guess i could have just said Extraordinary and ordinary forms coexist.

Comment: With dual citizenship, one can still collect their SS checks.  Been looking into it since I've decided to move to Taiwan (headed there Monday to start looking for my home).  With some countries, you can even become a citizen of their country yet still collect SS.  What matters is if their social programs are giving you money.  That effects the amount you can collect from our SS system. If you move to another country, continue to work and contribute to their system, their laws will govern how much you are approved to collect.  It depends on country, but the few I know of you have to contribute a specified number of years to be provided benefits.  It's not some magical "become a citizen then get handed a paycheck from the government" situation.

Comment: Not a word in this anti-constitutional screed is true. 

The Supreme Court has ruled half a dozen times - from 1840 to 1976 - that the US government has the constitutional authority (Article IV, Section 3, Clause 2) to hold, regulate or dispose of land in any way it chooses. When the western states were formed, they relinquished all claims to federal land (often in their constitutions), which at that point was land that nobody wanted.

Since Teddy Roosevelt, federal lands have been set aside for the enjoyment and benefit of ALL Americans, and the vast majority of westerners support this.

The Hammonds were sent back to jail - NOT for what they did on their own land, but for multiple arsons on public land, to cover up illegal deer poaching and that put hunters and firefighters at risk for their lives, and they were illegally given lesser sentences initially than Congress had mandated.

Public lands in the western states bring millions of dollars to the local economies.

Comment: I have been a blue collar worker all of my life working for wages & being paid by the hour. I do not own a business & have no political power. This would lead to more frugal government when all citizens had to pay the bills & had something to lose. Politicians could not buy votes by promising to redistribute other people’s wealth with government benefits that the other guy has to pay for. Comment: Balance is an interesting aspect of any hockey game. Unlike football, if  you don't use your skill and grit  effectively to neutralize the other team's strength, rather than their weakness, you 'aint going to have much success in this league where it really counts. Given Buds' defence, its forwards have to come out with a much smarter and  grittier effort right from the first bell.  You can't neutralize and  expect the game to go your way if all you want to do is watch and dance around a little with the puck.  You have to play the whole game, from your head to your toes,  and  keep the elements of  grit and desire at the upper levels of your effort.  Unfortunately, at this time of the season, everyone who wants to stay in the run, plays tougher hockey; the greater lesson these kids must learn is that: to address their goals, they must play hard, at both ends of the rink.  Good luck in the next one.

Comment: I don't mind the tiny house concept, it beats living under bridges or exposed to the elements.   But the potential for similar communities to share resources and provide a higher levels of services is still out there.    Those without money still need to eat, to get job training, to send children to school, to have medical help for both physical and mental disabilities.

It's a wonderful goal to provide a centralized location for the homeless. Shelter is the most basic need on which to build a life.   I applaud the use of tiny homes.   

But we need to be sure this isn't a release of our communal guilt.   Shelter alone is not enough, it doesn't address the causes of poverty, mental health breakdown, violence, crime and other negative behaviors.  It a first bite out of larger problem.

I'm proud of Eugene for our accepting that the poor will always be with us.  It's an opportunity for all of us to examine how we react to the suffering of others and what that means to our own spirit.

Comment: Commissioner Ozias acted properly in supporting the request of members of our community who belong to Olympic Climate Action. This letter is addressed to our Federal leadership, not some corporate entity or institution. It is the stated policy of Clallam County to acknowledge the reality of climate change and it's impacts. The County is committed to working with the adaptation plan to mitigate the harm from such impacts.  The County is not entirely independent in it's ability to manage such impacts and will rely on inter-agency  and Federal support to accomplish this task.
We need to understand that our leadership at the top will not work at cross purposes with our stated goals and values. Asking our Senators to respect our interests and needs should not be seen as unusual or incompatible with the duties and responsibility of our elected County Commissioners. Commissioner Ozias understands this and I urge Commissioners Peach and Johnson to sign the letter and send it on.

Comment: Like it or not, some people have deeply felt religious concerns about homosexuality. Those concerns are supported, and even codified, by some established religious traditions. That’s a reality that can’t just be ignored, however repugnant we find it.

Religious freedom isn’t just for those we agree with. I find the idea of refusing service to somebody based on personal religious beliefs highly problematic, but that doesn’t mean I dismiss out of hand a person’s right to do so. 

I haven’t made up my mind on this issue. I just want people to understand it’s complexity. It isn’t just about Michael Phillips. It’s also about you and me and whether or not the state has the right to coerce us into actions we find morally objectionable.

Comment: If one looks at the annual inflation rates provided from January 2009, one can see why our central bank would want to delay this initial release to the Yuletide. In August 2008, arguably the month when the Canadian economy went into recession, the three new measures show inflation rates ranging between 2.5% and 2.7%, the rejected CPIX measure shows inflation of 1.7%. Just how, pray tell, does a central bank justify drastic interest rate cuts when the preferred measures of underlying inflation are well above the 2% target and closing in on the 3% upper bound? The CPIX measure quite properly excluded the mortgage interest cost index, while the three new measures do not exclude any series. So now the Bank of Canada is the only inflation-targeting central bank in the world that includes mortgage rate changes in its preferred measures of underlying inflation, which is against all reason. Only an incompetent Finance Minister like Morneau ever would have signed off on this.

Comment: Steve:  if you are going to opine, you owe it to your readers to describe the facts accurately.
1). There is another way to amend the Constitution that bypasses Congress.  Unlikely? Maybe.  But perhaps it would be more likely to succeed than going through Congress.
2).  Trump hasn't been elected by the Electoral College yet.  That won't happen until the 19th.  Don't get ahead of yourself.
3) The Constitution makes no provision for a popular vote for President.  If you don't believe me, I invite you to read the document for yourself. Article 2 Section 1 (as modified by the 12th Amendment) is a good place to start.  You will note the part about Electors being chosen by the state legislatures.   No popular election is required.  I'll bet that most who read this don't know this simple fact.  
Perhaps if more people would take an hour to actually read the document...and insist it be followed...we would all enjoy better governance.  What say you?

Comment: La Misericordia Bulla

Mercy for you, mercy from me.
Hosanna, mercy! Hosanna, me !

Dogma says “don’t”, doctrine says “whoa”!
Tradition says “halt”. Serviam? I say No.

Sin can be virtue, virtue be sin.
But mercy is mercy, Voila! Sin again.

Obstinate, harsh, rigid justice is wrong.
Mercy the prize, dance to my song.

Mercy the rock, the rock built on me.
So it is now and ever will be.

Mercy for all, unring the bell.
Satan is saved, though his real home is hell.

Mercy for you, mercy from me.
Hosanna, mercy! Hosanna, me!

Guy McClung; San Antonio TX
© 2016 http://www.catholiclane.com/poem-la-misericordia-bulla/

Comment: Since the author didn't really bother to answer the question seriously, I'll take a stab at it. 

Legally, if you smoke marijuana in your yard and it wafts into your neighbour's yard, that's a "nuisance" in the legal sense. Is it actionable as such? Possibly. If it interferes with your neighbour's reasonable enjoyment of his property, then yes he could sue you over it.

More practically, I think this is going to have to be handled by municipalities the way that other common nuisances are handled - through bylaws. As it stands many municipalities have already outlawed through bylaw open air burning. In Toronto, for instance, you can't have a fire pit in  your backyard, although cooking appliances are exempted.

As I see it, similar rules could come into force if marijuana use becomes a serious nuisance.

Comment: If the Canadian dollar were worth US78₵ for the month of July, this would imply a 3.7% increase in the exchange rate from June to July, the largest monthly increase since April 2016. However, as long as it is worth 77.6₵ or more, this would still imply an increase of at least 3.2%, and would still be the largest since April 2016. Whether this will stick or not is not clear. It seems that the market believes that Poloz, due to American pressure or whatever reason, now has pencilled in multiple increases in the overnight rate going forward. Doug Porter expects a 1.50% overnight rate by the end of 2018, which would finally take interest rates significantly above what Poloz inherited when he took office. If it looks like these will not be forthcoming the loonie could drop on the changed market expectations. It could be Poloz is no longer really in control and the Americans are dictating our monetary policy.

Comment: Rice's requests to unmask the names of Trump transition officials does not vindicate Trump's own tweets from March 4 in which he accused Obama of illegally tapping Trump Tower. This suggests Rice's unmasking requests were likely within the law.

Susan Rice, recall, was the National Security Advisor at the time, and most likely requested unmasking of names from intelligence reports all the time. Apparently some of those times included Trump transition officials. How many times? "Dozens." How does that compare to her usual number of requests? There's no telling. Does this have anything to do with Trump's original tweet? No. Was it illegal or wrong in any way? Probably not.

Comment: On your second question. I have more sympathy with Washington and Jefferson. They lived 150 years earlier - in a different world altogether - where most countries still practiced slavery (including the cape colony by the way). 
And both of them were vocally opposed to it. They participated in it as that was how the world worked, but both called for it to be ended. Jefferson set all his slaves free in his last will and testament for example.

They did good things, worth remembrance, and bad things which we must not condone. But overall their good actions outweigh their bad - if only because they RECOGNIZED the bad for what it was and admitted it was wrong.

There is no such mitigating circumstances for Lee. He lived in a time when the whole world had abolished slavery - and fought a treasonous war to defend it.  

Remember Lee for what he was: a racist who committed high treason because he thought he had the right own people.

Yes: it was high treason. The entire war was.

Comment: Just to correct a factual error: the US no longer has 10 times the population of Canada (which those of us who are old enough remember it being for decades). Due to differences in growth, largely related to immigration, the US only has 9 times the population (316.5 M vs. 35.16 M as of 2013, 322.8 M vs. 36.3 M as of 2016, dropping from 9x to 8.9x over 3 years), and under the current US administration that difference in growth is only likely to accelerate. Given the factors that other commentators here have mentioned, and the new EU deal (EU-28 pop. 510.1 M in 2016), while Canada may not have blunt leverage as the article suggests, our vulnerability in a trade war with the US is diminishing over time. The Liberal gov't should be hedging their bets that way even as they avoid poking the US admin. in the eye.

Comment: Yes, the UGB is an arbitrary line, and even if we don't expand it, people can still "drive 'till they qualify" in Junction City or other neighboring cities if there isn't enough affordable housing in Eugene. But that doesn't do much to address transportation options and climate change.

We need a balance between the different pillars, and a multitude of solutions to address the issues. Yes, incentives to ensure more workforce housing (and more subsided housing for those with very low income), identifying areas where higher-intensity infill could be incentivized, and perhaps even adding additional land are part of the solution.  But the piece of the solution that includes removing roadblocks to additional market rate and missing middle infill shouldn't be taken off the table.

Comment: The evidence from British Columbia demonstrates that a revenue-neutral carbon tax can reduce carbon emissions significantly while maintaining economic productivity, and the I-732 carbon tax is arguably better crafted than BC's.  Arguing that the Paris Accord's provisions don't go far enough is not adequate justification for doing nothing; everyone around the world needs to not only meet but surpass the Paris Accord, and the idea of constant striving for better is build into the Accord. Nuclear energy would not be subject to the I-732 carbon tax,  but nuclear expansion will not alone serve our need for a transitional energy source due to its costs and long start-up time.

Comment: I salute your candor, and your willingness to listen to the more reasonable partisans (there were some, including in my own suburban town) of the demagogue. It is too easy to stereotype and paint with a broad brush. Some of us are appalled by this person who will be in the 2017 White House, yet are uncomfortable to an extreme with "identity politics". My faith teaches me we are called to lift up everyone, and that politics should not be a zero sum game. It should not be necessary or desirable to label people as "marginalized" unless you are willing to include that unemployed white person in a hardscrabble Rust Belt town with a ruined downtown and a dead nephew from addiction to drugs. They are as much "marginalized" (and I'd say more so) than a gay or lesbian couple in a warm, safe suburban home with two incomes, or a black physician or professor in a brand new condo. 

Let us support lifting up all, with policies that respect all, and not be atomized into groups with axes to grind.

Comment: This is excellent news!  We live in a UO neighborhood that has been negatively impacted by investors turning single-family homes into student rentals.  Pack 5 students (and their five cars!) into a house and sit back to collect the rent without a care about the renters' behaviors or impact on the neighborhood.  In the last couple of years we can see the tide turning and several homes have gone on the market and are now owned and occupied by families.  We are convinced that the  new student high-rises are squeezing the market rates and causing some landlords to sell the single-family homes (also helped by increased home values).  This new tower on Franklin will put even more pressure on the market and, hopefully, get more students out of single-family homes in our neighborhood.  And, for the record, there are several large student housing buildings in our neighborhood (around Matt Arena and Franklin Blvd) and we are fine with that.  These high-rises are managed well.

Comment: John Nightingale was quoted more fully by CBC as saying,  "To the degree I can I urge people not to think about belugas as if they were people, which I hear a lot. Like, 'I couldn't imagine living in a pool like that.' Well, the beluga couldn't imagine living in your living room either.”

Two points. First, the aquarium itself is as guilty as anyone of anthropomorphizing the animals, as in their "name the baby beluga" contest. Whales have calves, not babies, and giving them cute names is a way of making them seem like family members instead of captive wild animals. 

Second, we get to leave our living rooms whenever we want. This is a deeply stupid analogy to justify penning up animals whose instinct is to roam over vast oceans.

Comment: I don't think that this nation was actually founded on a principle of work or starve; but even if it was, programs like SNAP were lawfully initiated and funded. If you figure we shouldn't have such programs, you can work to have them repealed, and get other like-minded people to join you. Meanwhile, tough talk like "if you don’t work, you don’t eat" doesn't make much sense when jobs get scarce. We need to help each other out. And before you start spouting "taker" and "freeloader" and such at me, I've worked for my living since I was a teenager, and I have never used any government assistance. I count myself lucky to have been able to find work when I needed to; I know not everyone has been that fortunate.

So, what's your solution for areas where there aren't many jobs available? If people are able to work, and can prove that they've been actively seeking work, but there just aren't jobs to be had, what then? What's the result of "if you don’t work, you don’t eat" when there's no work?

Comment: Initially the train would mainly serve people without cars, and those for whom driving to a single destination might be too-expensive or too-stressful.  Such a train would work well for Broncos, Rockies, Avs and Nuggets games as long as its cost was subsidized by a similar percentage as RTD's light rail is now.  It could also serve Air Force and CSU football games. 

I don't see the more-expensive train at this point but perhaps our rail commission should look into standard off the shelf mid-speed rail equipment already in use in the US such as the Acela or Metroliner trains in-use on the East Coast.  The Metroliner trains are capable of 110-120 mph on good straight track and the newer Acela trains do about 155 mph.  

Such a system might put on a baggage car or two and also haul small packages to and from Denver or the other stops to help with the cost.  I could see maybe 4-6 trains daily from Ft Collins to Pueblo, which should take maybe 2 to 2.5 hours including 7-10 stops.

Comment: "When you don’t get the CPP survivor benefit you expect"

Great article - should be mandatory reading for all CPP contributors.

CPP is the only pension plan in the world that does not provide a survivor's benefit commensurate with the deceased's pension plan contributions.

Why not - you may ask?

Well - when I complained after my wife died 12 years ago, I was told doing so would not be fair to single people. What utter hogwash!

Did my wife not contribute the maximum each working year when she was alive?

Did we not contribute to the Canadian economy by having children, buying a house, buying cars, etc., etc., etc.?

So, why doesn't CPP provide a survivor's benefit commensurate with the deceased's pension plan contributions?

It's time for the Feds to clear the air on this issue!

Comment: "Statistics Canada data show that males at age 65 could expect to live an extra 19 years, and women an extra 22 years."

Correct....sort of.  What the data shows is that males age 65 ON AVERAGE could expect to live an extra 19 years.  This means that half of men age 65 will still be living at age 84 and at that point will STILL have and AVERAGE life expectation of another 7.6 years.  Also, what the tables show is that someone age 60 has a shorter AVERAGE life expectancy overall than someone age 65.  And someone age 65 has a shorter AVERAGE life expectancy than someone age 70.  Bottom line is that it's complicated!

I'm 67 (not collecting yet) and still working but likely to retire within the next year. I will most likely delay CPP and OAS until age 70 for two reasons.  First is because I can afford to wait.  Second is because I don't know anywhere else where you can get a guaranteed 8% return on an investment.

Comment: Another option, when conflict does occur, is to seek assistance from a mediator. Mediation is a voluntary process in which a neutral third party facilitates the negotiations of those involved in the conflict. The parties craft their own solution to the problem that can go beyond what a Court could ultimately decide and the process can bring finality, closure and certainty all at a fraction of the cost of drawn out Court proceedings. Disputes among family members are particularly well suited to mediation given the range and intensity of issues usually involved.
